title: 'We have to keep going': Bryce Harper gone but not forgotten as Nationals bask in World Series
text:
CLOSE SportsPulse: Yes, it's fun to point out the Nationals got to the World Series a year after Bryce Harper left. No, he's not the reason one way or the other they got there. Current Nats explain. USA TODAY

HOUSTON – Just to be certain, He Who Is Not Here is hardly looming over the proceedings at Minute Maid Park.

At the same time, as the Washington Nationals play in their first World Series, Bryce Harper is out of sight, but rarely out of the minds of casual observers wondering how a franchise could lose its icon and go where it never has.

Harper’s departure to the Philadelphia Phillies for a $330 million contract his old club was not willing to match, followed by said club’s 93-win grind of a season and stunning 8-2 march to the National League pennant creates the temptation to oversimplify.

With Harper: Nationals can’t get out of first round.

Without: Unstoppable playoff force.

With Harper: Dugout choke holds.

Without: Dugout dance parties.

But of course, it’s never that simple.

For one, the Nationals chose wisely in spending $140 million on free agent lefty Patrick Corbin, creating a pitching-heavy roster that has mostly dominated opponents in a manner Gio Gonzalez and Co. never could in October.

The Nationals also enjoyed the fortune of good sequencing. In short: It all went to hell early on, from a bullpen that turned the eighth inning into a nightly hallucination to a rash of early injuries that sidelined stalwarts Trea Turner, Anthony Rendon and Juan Soto.

Little wonder they started the year 19-31 – and that their fortunes turned when the big boys came back and the bullpen was repaired.

WORLD SERIES: Aces give this Fall Classic an old-school feel

RENDON: Nationals' MVP candidate back in his hometown

The Nationals made the playoffs in four of Harper’s seven seasons; his .900 career OPS is the best in the franchise’s Washington history, and he was the 2015 NL MVP.

“He played great. He did a lot of things people have never done from ages 19 to 25, so he deserves everything that he got,” says veteran infielder Ryan Zimmerman.

Soto, who like Harper debuted at 19 and proceeded to put up historic numbers for his age, won’t soon forget the manner in which No. 34 eased his transition to the bigs upon debuting in May 2018.

“He was always right there for me,” Soto said of Harper. “That was the first guy I saw when I come up here – he just gave me a hug and said ‘Hey, anything you need, we’re going to be here.’

“We’re really sad we lost him, but we have to keep going, we have to keep playing baseball. We play as a team and try to play baseball and enjoy.”

That they did, finishing 74-38 after their dismal start to claim the NL’s top wild-card spot.

A fan mocks Bryce Harper during the NLCS. (Photo: Brad Mills, USA TODAY Sports)

Harper wasn’t as fortunate, at least on the field. The Phillies finished 81-81, fired manager Gabe Kapler and for now lack the bedrock of starting pitching that will make the Nationals and New York Mets almost certain contenders in 2020.

Off the field? The Nationals know he’s rich in more than just a monetary sense.

“Bryce did so much for this organization and he even said it – he made the best decision for his family,” says Rendon, a pending free agent who may be playing his final games as a National himself. “I’m so happy for him. I couldn’t be more thrilled for him and they welcomed a child into this world as well.”

But what about that whole can’t-win-a-playoff-series curse – and not even making the playoffs his final year?

“But it’s so hard to make the playoffs,” Rendon insists, “as much as everybody thinks it’s so easy. And they think, ‘It’s not that hard to win a Division Series, and do this, do that.'

“The amount of games we play, the grind we endure, it’s tough.”

They fought through this year, with second-year manager Dave Martinez finding his groove, midseason acquisition Gerardo Parra gaining considerable clubhouse and cultural currency with his gregarious nature and kid-friendly walk-up jam.

Even typically laconic ace Stephen Strasburg seemed like a different man this year, waltzing with Parra after winning the NL pennant and partaking in the perfunctory dugout dance party after a startling home run.

“We have a lot of guys who like to have a lot of fun,” Strasburg said by way of explaining his apparently newfound exuberance. “And I’m not one to be a Debbie Downer.”

Tuesday night, the Nationals will soak in all that comes with a World Series appearance, and should they snag a game off the Houston Astros here, can count on a raucous welcome at Nationals Park for Friday’s Game 3.

As Zimmerman glanced around at the media throngs and the field below, October legends waiting to be made, he pondered the future of his old mate. Fourteen years is a long time – long enough for fortunes to turn, and, perhaps, for everyone to have a happy ending.

“I hope he obviously has an unbelievable career,” Zimmerman said of Harper, “and gets to do this.

“There’s some part of me that somehow thinks he will.”
description: After homegrown superstar Bryce Harper left for Philadelphia, the Washington Nationals pulled off a miraculous run to the World Series.
